metadata.sermon_start_end: A great many people my age have had the somewhat unnerving experience of learning that our grandchildren are at home in a world of electronic technology that we will never really master. [...] Where sin increased, grace abounded all the more, so that, as sin reigned in death, grace also might reign through [God’s] righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on Romans 5, but spends significant time on cultural critique (Margaret Mead) before engaging the text. It identifies the specific Pauline concept of Sin as a 'reigning monarch' rather than discrete acts, which is a strong textual observation.
quotes: This passage from Romans depicts Sin as a reigning monarch, in league with its fellow tyrant Death, advancing through the world like an annihilating army.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Reduce the lengthy sociological introduction to allow the specific 'nowhere else' quality of Romans 5—the cosmic 'much more' of Christ's obedience—to dominate the sermon's structure from the start.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates theological depth, likely informed by the mentioned Käsemann commentary. The distinction between 'sin' and 'Sin' (as a power) reflects a solid understanding of Pauline theology and the original Greek nuance.
quotes: The usual way is to think of a sin here and a sin there... but even that great prayer doesn’t quite get at the heart of Paul’s conception.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: While the exegesis is sound, it is used more as a lecture on Pauline thought than an unfolding of the specific historical context of the Roman congregation.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is sharp and polemical. It attacks the 'zeitgeist' of 1960s optimism and modern consumerism. It is concrete regarding the 'fear-ridden world' of post-9/11 security and the ethics of torture.
quotes: To come here on the plane, I had to take off my shoes, belt, jewelry... Is that an open and free world?
Americans are seriously considering the betrayal of our own highest values by... torturing prisoners.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: The application leans heavily on cultural philosophy; it needs to connect the 'reign of grace' more concretely to the congregation's daily spiritual life beyond political critique.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is somewhat bifurcated. It begins with a long sociological essay on Margaret Mead, then moves into the Bible passage. The 'mixing' Dekker demands is present in the latter half, but the start is detached from the Word.
quotes: At the height of the youthquake that occurred in the late 1960s... Margaret Mead gave some lectures...
On this first Sunday in Lent, we do not come together for worship in order to exhort one another... instead, we are recalled to an old, old story.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the critique of Mead directly into the exposition of Adam, rather than treating it as a separate introductory lecture.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon excels here. It takes 'misery' (the reign of Sin and Death) with absolute seriousness, refusing to soften it. Redemption is clearly extra nos (outside ourselves), and gratitude is framed as the 'mark of a Christian' in behavior.
quotes: The axis of evil has gained dominion everywhere, in every human heart.
The distinguishing mark of Christians is the way we behave when other people are in our power.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' section (the Christian response) is as robustly developed as the 'misery' section.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'two ways' by contrasting the 'iron rule of Sin' with the 'reign of Grace.' It explicitly rejects the liberal notion that man can create his own future, emphasizing the possibility of being 'lost' in a 'sickness-unto-death.'
quotes: no one has been able to choose to step outside the iron rule of Sin and Death.
we are all born into a condition of rebellion and sickness-unto-death.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The 'two ways' could be more explicitly framed as a call to decision for the hearer, rather than a description of two cosmic states.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the clear telos. The sermon emphasizes the 'two natures' (the new man who is God's gift) and the absolute necessity of grace over human effort. The Cross is the only way of victory.
quotes: There is only one new human being, and he is Jesus Christ. He is the new man who is able to create a new humanity.
The only way of victory is through the Cross.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Maintain the focus on Christ's victory as an objective reality even when discussing the 'lifestyles' of the youth.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1950 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under the 20-minute threshold at a measured pace. It has the 'breadth' Miskotte requires, though the first third is more cultural commentary than biblical depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Shift the word count balance from the Margaret Mead analysis toward more 'breadth' in the exposition of the Romans text itself.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a robust theological critique of modern optimism, grounded in a serious reading of Pauline hamartiology. It falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily in its structure: the lengthy sociological introduction on Margaret Mead delays the actualization of the Word. However, it succeeds in treating Sin and Grace as objective powers rather than mere psychological states.
strengths: Uncompromising view of human misery and the 'reign of Sin'.
Strong Christocentric focus where grace is the only solution.
Concrete application regarding contemporary issues like security and torture.
weaknesses: The introduction is too long and detached from the specific Bible passage.
The sermon borders on a lecture in its first half.
Slightly under the 20-minute requirement for 'depth' according to Dekker's strict rule.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a sermon in the sense of Dekker’s definition because it refuses 'general truths' and 'starry-eyed' optimism, instead confronting the hearer with the specific, concrete reality of the 'two ways' and the 'one Lord'. It requires more structural interwoveness to be truly exceptional.
